exercise.pack.title: Distance from a Point to a Hyperplane: Exercises

para.para.body: Recall that the projection of a vector \Vect{x} in \RNr[n] onto the line L through the origin and in the direction of the nonzero vector \Vect{y} is
Which of the following is true?
This projection is a real number.

info.caption: Comment on ‘This projection is a real number.’

para.para.body:
Sorry! No! – If n > 1 , and you project a vector on a line, you get .... ? – If n=1 this projection is what?
a number, namely the original number x
This projection is a vector.

info.caption: Comment on ‘This projection is a vector’

para.para.body: Correct! – The projection of \Vect{x} onto L is a multiple of the vector \Vect{y} .
This projection is a line.

info.caption: Comment on ‘This projection is a line’

para.para.body: No! - We start with a vector \Vect{x} , and projecting it onto a line L yields a single vector, contained in L .
If \proj_{L}(\Vect{x}) = 0 , what can you conclude about \Vect{x} in relation to the line L ?
If \Vect{x} = \Vect{0} , its projection onto L will be the 0 -vector. However, in general, this is not the reason why \proj_{L}(\Vect{x}) = \Vect{0} .
I conclude that \Vect{x} lies on L
Sorry, no! If \Vect{x} lies on L , its projection onto L will be \Vect{x} itself.
I conclude that \Vect{x} is perpendicular to L .

info.caption: Comment on: \Vect{x} is perpendicular to L
